title_sort: william e. vandemark to walt whitman, 29 december 1863
title: William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 29 December 1863
text: Dear fatherto day i[I] received a letter from yo[you] and i[I] was glad to here from yo[you] i[I] am not very well and have not ben[been] for some time i[I] have pain in my head and breast i[I] think the clorform[chloroform] that i[I] have taken is the caus[cause] of it my hip is very painful to day i[I] was exasamend[examined] i[I] think that i[I] will go before the board in a day or two i[I] may get my discharge i[I] have hurd[heard] that my ridgement[regiment] is going home for the winter to recruit thair[there] is only 17 men left inny[any] more for duty father i[I] long to see yo[you] and have a talk with yo[you] i[I] will try and get a pas to go to Washington to see yo[you] after i[I] have ben[been] before the board for another exsamanation[examination]father i[I] hope yo[you] had a good time a Crismis[Christmas] & i[I] hope yo[you] en Joyed yiour[your] Self wat[what] a blessed privelge[privilege] it is to be so that we can en Joy the privelage[privilege] wile some are on beds of sickness and have ben[been] cut off in their youth—dear father i[I] wish yo[you] a happy new yrs and a good time i[I] will try and get a pas to come and see yo[you] next friday[Friday] i[I] hante[haven't] sure of getting one yet but i[I] will try to get one—i[I] like this place very well here i[I] will never go to new york agin[again] on a trans bus for they use men thair[there] worse than dogs i[I] would have done better if i[I] had staid in washington[Washington] they know how to use men thair[there] and how to tak[take] cair[care] of them wen i[I] see yo[you] i[I] will tel[tell] yo[you] allI think the war is nearly ended now I hope it is at all events, for thair[there] has been men enuf[enough] lost on both sides in one war how many widows and orphans it has caused all ready—i[I] wish that i[I] could get detailed in washington[Washington] at some thing that i[I] coud[could] do i[I] woud[would] be very glad and would try to do my duty—father let me Know how things gets a long in army squair[square] tel[tell] crain that hante[haven't] had answer from the letter that i[I] sent him and i[I] would like to here from him i[I] have seen hathford wen i[I] was home and had a talk with him he is all rite nowfather i[I] will close good by dear father and friend from a friend William E Vandermark to a dear friend Walt Whitman good by William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 29 December 1863
